lg.l: Where do sunbeams brightest glisten,
‘Mid intricacies of shade;
Where does love-lorn tui Author’s note: The tui, or parson-bird, one of the honeysuckers peculiar to New Zealand. listen
To its mate in leafy glade;
Where, when earliest spring is waking
From their sleep each leaflet’s fold,
Do the zephyrs, gently shaking[,]
Pave the kowhai’s Author’s note: The kowhai is a native acacia, that in spring is covered with a profusion of golden blossoms. roots with gold;
Where, with melody surprising,
Does the bell-bird Author’s note: The bell-bird, or Moko Moko, another New Zealand honey-sucker, that always welcomes the dawn with a strangely clear and deep note, like a bell. welcome day,
Ere the golden sun arising
Makes the night mists roll away;
Where do great koninis, Author’s note: The konini is the giant fuchsia of New Zealand, whose numberless purple berries are the delight of birds and children. laden
With their million berries store,
Purple lips of many a maiden?
‘Tis in lovely Akaroa. Akaroa. Akaroa is the name of a harbour and small town on Banks Peninsula, in the Canterbury region of the South Island of New Zealand.
Where do mighty tree-clad mountains Mountains. Banks Peninsula is an extinct, eroded volcanic complex
Solemn guard the vales below,
Giving birth to many a fountain,
Where in winter lies the snow;
Where do great totaras, Author’s note: The totara is a pine with golden or bronze-colored foliage, of great beauty. It grows to an enormous size. flinging
Bronzed foliage to the sky,
Rest a thousand songsters singing
Hymns of rapture ere they fly;

Where are giant willows Author’s note: The weeping willows growing in Akaroa are all said to have sprung from a slip brought by a Frenchman from Napoleon’s tomb at St. Helena. They are of enormous size. growing,
From Napoleon’s distant grave;
Where are creeks for ever flowing,
Giving verdure as they lave;
Where do sunclad wavelets wander
To Zealandia’s fairest shore,
In embracing growing fonder?
‘Tis in lovely Akaroa.
Where do sunsets[‘] rays of glory,
Gold and purple raiment, throw
O’er the hills Author’s note: The hills around Akaroa were the scenes of many a renowned Maori conflict. renowned in story
In the Maori long ago;
Where does wild clematis, Author’s note: The wild clematis, with snowy blossoms fully a foot in circumference, is of marvellous beauty. flinging
Tendrils o’er the boughs below,
Cover sprays where birds are singing
With a cloak of purest snow;
Where, in wild, sequestered valley,
Grows the wondrous Nikau Author’s note: The Nikau palm grows only in the most sequestered and sheltered valleys. palm,
Forming ever-verdant alley,
Where there is eternal calm;
Where are silver fern-trees Author’s note: The silver fern-tree’s fronds are a brilliant green above and pure silver underneath. spreading
Fairy fronds of beauty pure,
A perpetual fragrance shedding?
‘Tis in lovely Akaroa.
Where, when storms are raging madly,
‘Neath the bitter tempest’s blast,
Does the sailor enter gladly,
Finding peaceful seas at last;
Where does the titoki’s Author’s note: The titoki is the native ash. It bears masses of scarlet berries like gigantic raspberries. glory
Blaze with scarlet many a glade,
Sheltered from nor’-westers’ Author’s note: The nor’-westers are hot winds in Akaroa, and wither vegetation. fury
By the pine Author’s note: The native bush consisted originally principally of gigantic pines. trees’ tasselled shade;
Where are feet for ever pressing
Wondrous ferns Author’s note: The ferns in Akaroa are of marvellous variety and beauty. of beauty rare,
Robed in Nature’s choicest dressing,
Ever fresh and passing fair;
Where, when from the world we sever,
Seeking peace for evermore,
Should we choose to rest for ever?
‘Tis in lovely Akaroa.
